summary.p: Bifolio; Writing surface: paper; Shelfmark: KFQ 72; Lines per page: 7; Dimensions: 215 x 177 mm; Script style: New Style I; Estimated date of production: 1000-1200 .

Cf. catalogue entry by F. Déroche about fragment KFQ 72 (The Abbasid Tradition, London 1992, p. 176-177): "93 / Bifolio / 11th or 12th century AD / 21.5 x 17.7cm, with 7 lines to the page / Material A thin, brittle, deep buff paper, laid, with 4-5 lines to the centimetre; the lines run perpendicular to the spine / Text area 13.7 x 12cm / Script NS.I / Accession no. KFQ 72 / This fragment belongs to a later development of NS.I style. Mannerism pervades the script: the letter forms are often contorted and may even include extraneous elements, which suggests a close relationship with epigraphic material. It is possible to find similar forms of lām-alif, initial ʿayn, and hāʾ , which has a short spur at the base of the letter, and the same type of ligatures in dated manuscripts from the end of the 11th century, such as the Qurʾ an of AH485 (ADI092) in the collection of Aga Mahdi Kashano (Lings 1976, p.18, pls 14-16). However, this fragment should probably be ascribed to the 12th century. / The text consists of Sūrat Maryam (XIX), verses 76-82, and Sūrat ṭāʾ-hāʾ (XX), verses 40-47. It is written in black ink, with diacritical dots. The modern vowel signs are written in red, with the shaddah in blue. Individual verses are punctuated by 3.1.2 devices, while the pear-shaped ornaments inserted into the text at the end of each group of five verses are matched by 3.A.II medallions in the margin, which contain the word khams ('five') written in gold. The ends of the groups of ten are marked by a 3.C.II device, with the number of verses written out in gold New Style script on a red ground."
Unfortunately only a small selection of images from this manuscripts (as in the catalogue Abbasid Tradition, p. 176f.) are on display in this catalogue.
